TRSUBCHAPTER: The regulations on the Dharma of the four āśramas

PARAL.rm: Testimonia for this chapter: \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 208v--210r, \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 214r--215v, \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 285v--287v, \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 15v--17v, \msNb\ ff.\thinspace 221v--223v (exp.\thinspace 56 lower -- 58 lower), \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 223v--225v; \Ed\ pp.\thinspace 613--617; \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc

NOTE: I understand Łpāda$ c as containing a sandhi bridge thus: Łalpakleśa-m-anāyāsa$. The sandhi between Łpāda$s c and d is irregular, understand °Łanāyāsaḥ artha$°, or rather °Łanāyāso 'rtha$°.

The beginning of the \SDHS\ (\SDHS\ 1.7--11) expresses a similar sentiment, using the word Łāyāsa$, similarly to \VSS\ 11.1c above, but giving a somewhat clearer reason for asking for a new form of devotion, namely that twice-born members of society with limited financial resources struggle to perform expensive Vedic rituals (Łna śakyante yataḥ kartim alpavittair dvijātibhiḥ$): sanatkumāra uvāca | bhagavan sarvadharmajña śivadharmaparāyaṇaḥ | śrotukāmāḥ paraṃ dharmam imaṃ sarve samāgatāḥ || agniṣṭomādayo yajñā bahuvittakriyānvitāḥ | nātyantaphalabhūyiṣṭhā bahvāyāsasamanvitāḥ || na śakyante yataḥ kartum alpavittair dvijātibhiḥ | sukhopāyam ato brūhi sarvakāmārthasādhakam || hitāya sarvasatvānāṃ śivadharmaṃ sanātanam | nandikeśvara uvāca | śrūyatām abhidhāsyāmi sukhopāyamahatphalam || paramasarvadharmāṇāṃ śivadharmaṃ śivātmakam | śivena kathitaṃ pūrvaṃ pārvatyāḥ ṣaṇmukhasya ca ||.
TEXT: na tulyaṃ tava paśyāmi dayā bhūteṣu bhāmini|
NOTE: I understand Łdayā$ in Łpāda$ b as instrumental: Łtava dayayā bhūteṣu na tulyaṃ paśyāmi$. Alternatively, as suggested by Csaba Dezső, Łpāda$s ab could be interpreted as two sentences: `I cannot see anything comparable to you. [You have great] compassion towards living beings, O Bhāminī.'

Note Łme$ for Łmayā$ in Łpāda$ b, and the evident distinction here between Maheśvara, the interlocutor, and Sadāśiva, who, in this context seems to be superior, being the ultimate source here of the following teaching. This might hint at a familiarity with the Tantric sequence of Łtattva$s, on which see, e.g., NisvasaGoodall45.
TEXT: vinārthena tu yo yajñaḥ sa yajñaḥ sārvakāmikaḥ|
APP: \vb yajñaḥ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; yajña \Ed\oo sārvakāmikaḥ \msCb\Ed; sarvakālikaḥ \msCa\msNc, sarvakāmika \msCc, sārvakālikaḥ \msNa, sārvakāmikāḥ \msNb
PARAL: \vab See a sequence or list of the four āśramas in 4.75 above: gṛhastho brahmacārī ca vānaprastho 'tha bhaikṣukaḥ; see also 5.9: etac{ }chaucaṃ gṛhasthānāṃ dviguṇaṃ brahmacāriṇām| vānaprasthasya triguṇaṃ yatīnāṃ tu caturguṇam||
NOTE: I put a question mark after the subchapter heading here because in this chapter the category of the Łgṛhastha$ never gets mentioned. It is simply labelled Łāśramaḥ prathamaḥ$ in 11.25a. Nevertheless, the category Łgṛhastha$ is most probably implied and elsewhere mentioned (see 4.74c, 5.9a, and 15.17a, which reads Łāśramāṇāṃ gṛhī śreṣṭho$). The teaching on sacrifice without materials (Łvinārthena yajñaḥ$ or Łanarthayajñaḥ$), which is fundamentally internalised sacrifice, is a central teaching of the \VSS: in addition to the present chapter, the expression appears as the main interlocutor's name (Anarthayajña) in chapters 1--9 and 19--21, and his life is discussed in chapter 22. Thus the name Anarthayajña or the concept of Łanarthayajña$ appears in each major layer of the text. On this see p. \verify, and KissVolume2021.
APP: \vd pravibhāga° \msCb; pravibhoga° \msCa\msCc(?)\msNa\msNc\Ed, pratibhoga° \msNb\oo °phalā smṛtā \msCc; °phalaḥ smṛtaḥ \msCapcorr\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc, °phala smṛtaḥ \msCaacorr, °pradaḥ smṛtaḥ \Ed
NOTE: The context of Łpāda$s cd is this: Viśvarūpa was a son of Tvaṣṭṛ. Viśvarūpa's heads were struck off by Indra and Indra's sin were distributed among the ground, water, trees and women. See e.g.\ \BHAGP\ 6.9.6: brahmahatyām añjalinā jagrāha yad apīśvaraḥ | saṃvatsarānte tad aghaṃ bhūtānāṃ sa viśuddhaye | bhūmyambudrumayoṣidbhyaś caturdhā vyabhajad dhariḥ ||. (`Even though [Indra was] the Lord, he took on himself, with folded hands, the sin of killing a Brāhmaṇa. At the end of the year, [he,] Hari distributed that sin in four parts to the earth, water, trees and women for the self-purification of living beings.')
TEXT: śodhite tu phalaṃ śuddham{ }aśuddhe niṣphalaṃ bhavet||
NOTE: ŁPāda$ a is unmetrical unless the so-called muta cum liquida licence is applied for the first syllable of Łprathamaṃ$, turning the line into a Łna-vipulā$.

Sets of five types of purification are a commonplace in Tantric Śaivism, but they are usually somewhat different form what we see here. They usually include Łātmaśuddhi, sthānaśuddhi, dravyaśuddhi, mantraśuddhi$ and Łliṅgaśuddhi$. See Goodall's article on this in \TAKIII\ s.v. Łdravyaśuddhi$.
The passage 11.10-11 is in fact prose.
TEXT: vidhim{ }evaṃ yadā śudhyed{ }yadi yajñaṃ karoti hi|
APP: \vab śudhyed{ }yadi \conj; sūyed{ }yadi \msCa\msNa, pūrya yadi \msCb, sūryed{ }yadi \msCc, sūyed{ }yati \msNb, pūyed{ }yadi \msNc, śūddhya yadi \Ed
NOTE: An alternative to my conjecture in Łpāda$ a (Łyadā śudhyed$ for Łyadā sūyed$, Łsūryed$, Łpūrya$, and Łpūyed$) has been suggested by Dominic Goodall. One could apply the reading of \msCb\ thus: Łyadāpūrya$ (`when having completed').
TEXT: vinārthena tu yo yajñaṃ karoti varasundari|
NOTE: I tentatively interpret Łsarvayajñeṣu$ in Łpāda$ d as a locative for genitive, and in a sense that does not reflect the meaning in which I took Łsarvayajñaḥ$ in 11.1a above. Compare the conclusion of this section, 11.24cd: āsahasrasya yajñānāṃ phalaṃ prāpnoti nityaśaḥ.

It would be easy to correct Łyajñavāṭa$ in Łpāda$ a to Łyajñavāṭaḥ$, and to normalise all the similarly positioned stem form nouns in the following verses because there are no metrical constrains that would prevent us from doing it, but it seems to me that there is a pattern here and these stem forms give the impression of being emphasised, highlighted, or being items in a list (see 11.14c and d, 15a, 16a and b, 17a, 18d, etc.). Nevertheless, some of the expression in the upcoming verses should be interpreted as bahuvrīhis qualifying the sacrificer/yogin. In fact, we could read Łyajñavāṭakurukṣetraḥ$ and Łpratyāhāramahāvediḥ$ as bahuvrīhis here.
Kurukṣetra was defined as an internalised pilgrimage place in 10.12, which fits well the presently introduced teaching of internalised sacrifice. Both are summarised, together with bodily penance, in 13.2 as: svaśarīrasthito yajñaḥ svaśarīre sthitaṃ tapaḥ | svaśarīre sthitaṃ tīrthaṃ śruto vistarato mayā ||. The term Łsattvāvāsa$ has elsewhere, but probably not here, a distinctively Buddhist flavour, denoting the seven or nine `abodes of beings,' see, e.g. EdgertonHybridvol.~2, s.v. Łsattvāvāsa$, and SferraTorellaVolArticle1155.

Note that if Łpāda$ c followed the pattern of Łpāda$ a, namely that `X in Vedic ritual is now Y in this internalised sacrifice,' we would need to read Łmahāvedi pratyāhāra$, but that would be unmetrical.
Łsaṃyama$ is mentioned only a few times in the \VSS\ (e.g., in a similar context, in 22.12), and is never explained, in contrast with the Łniyama$-rules mentioned in the next verse, which are expounded in detail in 5.1--8.44. Łsaṃyama$ may perhaps be used here in the sense in which it appears in the \YS: the yogic application, or appearance, of Łdhāraṇā$, Łdhyāna$, and Łsamādhi$ at the same time (see \YS\ 3.ff).
APP: \vb dhyānavahniḥ pradīpitaḥ \msNc; dhyānavahnipradīpitaḥ \msCa\msNa, dhyānaṃ vahnipradīpitaḥ \msCb, dhyānam{ }agnipradīpitaḥ \msCc, dhyāna agnipradīpanaḥ \msNb, dhyānavṛddhir{ }pradīpinaḥ \Ed
NOTE: I have chosen the reading of Łpāda$ b that is the easiest to interpret. Alternatively, the intended expression may have been Łdhyānena vahniḥ pradīpitaḥ$.
Instead of taking °Łsamijjvāla$° as a tatpuruṣa compound in Łpāda$ c (°Łsamidh-jvāla$°), consider emending it to °Łsamujjvāla$°, which would stand metri causa for °Łsamujjvala$°.
The interpretation of Łpāda$ b is tentative.

Ignoring the problems concerning grammatical gender and case, we may presume that the intended meaning in Łpāda$s cd could be expressed thus: Łājyāhutir avicchinnā lambikāsruvena pātitā$. I suspect that Łlambaka$ simply stands for Łlambikā$ (`uvula'), which fits the internalised nature of this ritual. See also Łghaṇṭikā$ possibly as `uvula' in 10.32d.
Understand Łpāda$s a as Łdhāraṇām adhvaryuvat kṛtvā$ (Łdhāraṇā$ in the MSS being in stem form).

Note how taking 11.14c and 15b together with the present verse, all six auxiliaries of the Łṣaḍaṅgayoga$ of \VSS\ chapter 16 have now been mentioned in this chapter. See 16.18: pratyāhāras tathā dhyānaṃ prāṇāyāmaś ca dhāraṇā | tarkaś caiva samādhiś ca ṣaḍaṅgo yoga ucyate || My interpretation of Łvayatāpana$ in Łpāda$ d as `burning of oblation' (Łvaya$ possibly standing for Łvayas$ metri causa) is tentative.

The final section of \VSS\ chapter 20, a chapter on the Łtattva$s of Sāṃkhya, discusses the mental state of Łunmanas$: unmanastvaṃ gate vipra nibodha daśalakṣaṇam | na śabdaṃ śṛṇute śrotraṃ śaṅkhabherīsvanād api ||, etc. Verse 11.50 below mentions Łmanonmanas$ in a similar context.
TEXT: śraddhā patnī viśālākṣi saṃkalpa pada śāśvatam||
NOTE: In Łpāda$ d, understand Łsaṃkalpaḥ padaṃ śāśvatam$ (both Łsaṃkalpa$ and Łpada$ are stem form nouns in the verse, the latter metri causa).

The term Łbrahmanāda$ in Łpāda$ c may refer to the same concept as Łbrahmabilasvara$ does in 11.29d. It may be the same as the (haṭha)yogic concept of Łmahānāda$ (`great sound' or `unstruck sound'), on which see MallinsonKhecari225, nn.~359 and 361. My translation tentatively presupposes that Łmantra$ in Łmahāmatra$ refers to Vedic mantras, now contrasted with a yogic experience. (See Łmahāmantra$ referring to Vedic/Śrauta mantras in \SKANDAP\ 13.132cd: śrutigītair mahāmantrair mūrtimadbhir upasthitaiḥ.)
Understand Łpāda$ d as Łprāyaścitto 'nilajayaḥ$. It would be possible to correct °Łcittānilo$ to °Łcitto 'nilo$, but since Ł'nilajayaḥ$ would be unmetrical and since stem form nouns abound in this chapter, I believe that Łprāyaścittānilo$ could be original.

Łcaturyamaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b is baffling. The \VSS\ teaches ten Yama-rules in 3.16--4.89. Dominic Goodall has suggested that Łcaturyamaḥ$ could stand for Łca tu yamāḥ$ metri causa. Another possibility would be to interpret Łcatur$ as Łcaturtha$ (`fourth') and then the phrase may refer to the fourth Yama-rule, absence of hostility (Łānṛśaṃsya$, 4.31--49).
Note the stem form Łitihāsa$ in Łpāda$ c, and the hiatus-filler Ł-m-$ in Łpāda$ c in °Łkṛta-m-ambaraḥ$ which is a metrical solution for °Łkṛto 'mbaraḥ$.

For the teaching on the internalised pilgrimage places Gaṅgā, i.e. Suṣumnā, and Yamunā, i.e. Iḍā, and their internalised confluence, Prayāga, see 10.17. Note that Iḍā and Suṣumnā are then reinterpreted as Somatīrtha and Sūryatīrtha, respectively, in 10.20--21.

Łsaṃtoṣa$° is either meant to be compounded with °Łatithim$ in Łpāda$ c or is in stem form for Łsaṃtoṣam atithiṃ$; for the latter possibility cf. e.g. 11.17a above. Similarly, °Łdvija$° may be in stem form in Łpāda$ d, for °Łdvijo 'rcitaḥ$, or simply correct it to °Łdvijo 'rcitaḥ$.

Note the stem form nouns in Łpāda$s ab.
On the Łbrahmakūrca$ observance, see, e.g., KaneHistoryvol.~4, 146, where the references given include \MITAKSARA\ ad \YAJNS\ 3.314: yadā punaḥ pūrvedyur upoṣyāparedyuḥ samantrakaṃ saṃyujya samantrakam eva pañcagavyaṃ pīyate tadā brahmakūrca ity ākhyāyate; `And when one fasts one day, and on the next day mixes the five products of the cow together while reciting mantras, and drinks [the mixture] while reciting mantras again, that is called Łbrahmakūrca$.'
On the Łguṇātīta$ state of mind, see 9.39--43. See the term Łnirañjana$ mentioned as a quality of the soul (Łjīva$) in 1.11 and 15.4, of the Łpuruṣa$ in 20.3, as a state of mind in 11.49, and as one of ten meditative states in 22.30.

It is difficult to know what are the three Łtattva$s mentioned in Łpāda$ c. (Understand Łtrayas tattvaṃ$ as Łtattvatrayaṃ$, Łtrīṇi tattvāni$, Łtritattvāni$, or Łtritattvaṃ$.) \VSS\ chapter 4 teaches four Łtattva$s as objects of meditation: Łātman$, Łvidyā$, Łbhava$, and Łsūkṣma$ (see, e.g., 4.73). \VSS\ chapter 6 discusses five Łtattva$s: Łsūrya$, Łsoma$, Łagni$, Łsphaṭika$, and Łsūkṣma$ (see, e.g., 6.7). \VSS\ chapter 20 enumerates the 25 Łtattva$s of Sāṃkhya. One possibility would be to interpret the set of three Łtattva$s as the three Łpadārtha$s of the Śaivasiddhānta, Łpati$, Łpaśu$, and Łpāśa$; see, e.g., \TAKIII, s.v. Łpatipaśupāśa$. Dominic Goodall has tentatively suggested reading here in \VSS\ 11.22c, with \msNa, Łbrahmasūtratrayaṃ tattvaṃ$ (`the three strands of the sacred thread is truth'). The problem is firstly that we have Łtrayas tattvaṃ$ repeated in 11.29c below, and secondly that what we need here is three entities compared to the three strands of the sacred thread. What is clear here is that even the investiture of the sacred thread (Łupanayana$) is supposed to be internalised in this teaching of non-material sacrifice.

My assumption is that Łpāda$ a here hints at those four, later five, categories, called Łkalā$s, that are well-known from Tantric Śaivism: Łnivṛtti$, Łpratiṣṭhā$, Łvidyā$, Łśānti$, and Łśāntyatīta$. For this, I had to emend the reading found in all witnesses consulted, Łnivṛtyā$°. I consider Łnivṛti$ for Łnivṛtti$ a common and plausible error. As Dominic Goodall has suggested, here the four Łkalā$s, originally possibly the four Śaktis of the Lord, may be reinterpreted as yogic states. The fact that the \VSS\ is aware of only four Łkalā$s here may hint at a relatively early date of composition of this section (see Introduction pp. \verify). On the history and interpretation of these Łkalā$s, see \TAKII\ s.v. Łkalā$ 6.
Łcatuḥprakaraṇāsanaḥ$ may be taken as Łcatuḥprakaraṇāṇy āsanam$, or, as I take it in my translation, a bahuvrīhi compound qualifying the practitioner. As to what the four Łprakaraṇa$s (`chapters'?) refer to here, I am without a clue. Perhaps the phrase was meaningful in a context whereof this section was taken out. The Mokṣopāya, a text of Kashmiri origin from the tenth century and made up of Łprakaraṇa$s would be an interesting candidate for being a point of reference. Unfortunately from this point of view, there are six Łprakaraṇa$s in the Mokṣopāya, and not four. See, e.g., SlajeMoksopaya1996\index{Moksopaya@\textsl{Mo\-kṣo\-pā\-ya}}.
APP: \vb kathitā te \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; kathito smi \msCc, kathitas{ }te \Ed\oo varānane \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; varānane \msCc
NOTE: Łsadāśivena$ in Łpāda$ c could also be interpreted as the agent of Łpūjitam$ in Łpāda$ d (`it is revered by Sadāśiva'), but Sadāśiva was mentioned as the original teacher of this ritual in 11.4 above, which makes it probable that he is being referred to in a similar manner here. Cf. also 11.30 below.

Łidaṃ$ in Łnibodhedaṃ$ in Łpāda$ a sounds clumsy with Łbrahmacaryaṃ$ (lit. `listen to this practice of chastity') but in fact the \MBH\ and the Purāṇas contain countless similar, albeit smoother, expressions, e.g., \MBH\ 5.145.15ab (duryodhana nibodhedaṃ kulārthe yad bravīmi te), \BRAHMAP\ 133.10ab (bharadvāja nibodhedaṃ vākyaṃ mama samāsataḥ), etc.
See some remarks on the life-stages, or social order of disciplines (Łāśrama$), and especially on their order, in the \VSS\ in KissVolume2021 and above on p.\verify

One could emend Łprakṛtir layam$ in Łpāda$ b to the expected Łprakṛtau layaḥ$ (see, e.g., \AGNIP\ 379.1d: vairāgyāt prakṛtau layam). Nevertheless, I retained the reading of \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed\ because it may have been the way in which the compound Łprakṛtilaya$ was originally made metrical. In other words, I suspect the Ł-r-$ to be only a link between the two elements of this compound. I also retained the neuter ending. Compare 16.8d, where the same expression is transmitted in all the witnesses so far consulted as Łprakṛtālayam$.

Note the stem form nouns in Łpāda$s cd (°Łsūtra$ and °Łālaya$). The `subtle syllable' may be Łoṃ$ (cf. 1.9--10), traditionally analysed as made up of three sounds, here corresponding to the three strands of the sacred thread. In Łpāda$ d, Łtriguṇālaya$ might rather mean `absorption in the three Qualities' (Łtriguṇeṣu layaḥ$) although in my translation I translate it as Łtriguṇa-ālayaḥ$.
TEXT: dama daṇḍa dayā pātraṃ bhikṣā saṃsāramocanam|
APP: \va daṇḍa dayā \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; daṇḍādayā \msNa, daṇḍādayo \Ed\oo pātraṃ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; pātra \msNb
NOTE: The Tryāyuṣa is a Vedic mantra, see, e.g., Ṛgveda-khila 5.3.6: tryāyuṣam jamadagneḥ kaśyapasya tryāyuṣam | agastyasya tryāyuṣam yad devānām tryāyuṣam tan no astu tryāyuṣam |; `The threefold vitality of [the sage] Jamadagni, that of [the sage] Kaśyapa, that which is that of the gods---may it be ours!' (translation based on SaivaUtopia202128). `In the Vedic domestic ritual codes, this is the mantra to be recited over the razor or over the student who is about to be shaven before bathing at the end of his studies' (ibid.). In \SIVAUP\ 5.20ab, this mantra is prescribed to accompany the application of the three lines on the forehead. Thus here in \VSS\ 11:28cd, Łtryāyuṣa$ and the mention of ashes make it clear that the next element of the ritual life of the Łbrahmacārin$ to be internalised is the application of the Łtripuṇḍra$. As for the Łdvyakṣarātīta$, which should be a mantra, it perhaps means a three-syllable mantra, possibly Ła-u-m$ or Łśivāya$.

On the problem of understanding what the three Łtattva$s are in this text, and on the phrase Łtrayas tattvaṃ$, see notes on verse 11.22 above. Perhaps Łbrahmabilasvara$ in Łpāda$ d refers to the same concept as Łbrahmanāda$ does in 11.19c.
APP: \vc mamāpi kathitaṃ tu° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; mamāpi kathitas{ }tu° \msNc, mayāpi kathito tu° \Ed
NOTE: One may consider correcting Łmamā$° to Łmayā$° (`it has been taught by Łme$'), but Łmama$, linked to the first hemistich, may be original, and Łapi$, then slightly unusually placed in the sense of `too/also' (as, e.g., in \RAGHU\ 5.44 and 9.8c), starting a new clause.
TEXT: adhibhūtaḥ smṛto mātā adhyātmaś{ }ca pitā tathā|
NOTE: I have accepted Dominic Goodall's suggestion to emend Ładhibhautika$ in Łpāda$ c to Ładhidaivika$. In this way, we arrive at the well-know triad of Ładhibhūta$, Ładhyātma$, and Ładhidaivika$ (or more often: Łādhibhautika$, Łādhyātmika$, and Łādhidaivika$; see, e.g. \YBH\ ad \YS\ 1.31 and 3.22, and \SK\ 1.1 in most commentators' interpretation). Ładhibhautika$ in Łpāda$ c may be the result of an eye-skip to Łpāda$ a, and the final Ł-m$ of Ładhidaivika$ could be interpreted as a hiatus-filler. The triad in question usually qualify three types of suffering or bad omen: pertaining to the material world, one's own self or body, and to the world of gods, respectively. Here in the \VSS, they seem to refer to realms of knowledge, or as \BhG\ 8.1--4, a possible source for the present verse, define them, Ładhibhūta$ is mundane existence, Ładhyātma$ is the eternal Brahman that is one's true nature, and Ładhidaivata$ is the Łpuruṣa$.
TEXT: śrutiḥ smṛtiḥ smṛtā bhāryā prajñā putraḥ kṣamānujaḥ|
NOTE: Łbhāryā$ in Łpāda$ a is probably meant to be in the dual (Łbhārye$) but the use of the singular could be original. Note how notions expressed by feminine nouns are associated with male relatives (Łprajñā$ is a son, Łkṣamā$ a brother).

In Łpāda$ c, Łjaṭā cāpaṃ$ is problematic. One would expect here an abstract notion corresponding to a real-life element of the forest-dweller life, as in the above verses. Łjaṭā$ and Łcāpa$ are either still identified with Łmaitrī$ (that is how I translate the Łpāda$) or there is a need to emend, e.g. to Łjaṭācāraḥ$ (`good conduct is his twisted hair'). I prefer the former solution because in this way the four Buddhist Łbrahmavihāra$s, Łmaitrī-karuṇā-muditā-upekṣā$, appear in one uninterrupted sequence. These may seem as being out of context in a Brahmanical text but the source for them may have been \YS\ 1.33: maitrīkaruṇāmuditopekṣāṇāṃ sukhaduḥkhapuṇyāpuṇyaviṣayāṇāṃ bhāvanātaś cittaprasādanam. See them mentioned also in verse 4.72 above, and in 11.56 below.
Note Łmauna$ in Łpāda$ e in stem form, and Łupekṣakā$ for Łupekṣā$, both metri causa.

I think that \msNc's Łjinādharaḥ$ in Łpāda$ b may be the original reading: it lengthens the final Ła$ of Łjina$° metri causa, and that the remaining sources try to restore the standard form of Łajina$ and thus ruin the metre. Cf., e.g., \MBH\ 1.123.18: sa kṛṣṇaṃ maladigdhāṅgaṃ kṛṣṇājinadharaṃ vane | naiṣādiṃ śvā samālakṣya bhaṣaṃs tasthau tadantike ||.
The accusative Łuttarāsaṅgam$ in Łpāda$ c is acceptable, but one may understand the final Ł-m$ as a hiatus-filler after a locative (°Łsaṅga āsīno$), or in the middle of a compound (°Łsaṅgāsīno$).
Łhāvana$ in Łpāda$ b stands fot Łhavana$ metri causa.
TEXT: jitaprāṇa mṛgākūlo dhṛti yajñaḥ kriyā japaḥ||
NOTE: I suspect that Ł°mṛgākūlo$ in Łpāda$ c stands for an unmetrical Łmṛgakulo$. Incidentally, even by inverting the order of the two elements in this Łpāda$, there would remain the metrical error of two Łlaghu$s: Łmṛgakulo jitaprāṇo$. Also, note °Łprāṇa$ and Łdhṛti$ in Łpāda$s cd as nouns in stem form.
See the word Łsaṃgraha$ (here in stem form) used probably in a similar sense in 11.46 below.
PARAL: \vd \compare\ \DHARMP\ 2.1: aṣṭabhiḥ sādhanair{ }ebhiś{ }cittaṃ kāyañ{ }ca yatnataḥ| śodhayitvā tato yogī yogābhyāsaṃ samācaret||
NOTE: See a reference to eight Łsādhana$s in \DHARMP\ 2.1 (quoted in the apparatus to the present verse in the critical edition). These may or may not reference the same set of practices.

The reading of the witnesses in Łpāda$ d, Łupāśrayet$, might be acceptable, but I consider my emendation, Łupāsayet$, better, especially because that is the verb used in 11.59d below, in a similar context.
ŁPāda$ b may allow for various interpretations. The one I have chosen seems to be the simplest. It involves a stem form noun, Łjapa$, and Łśāntaṃ$ in the sense of Łśāntiḥ$.
Understand the middle of Łpāda$s cd as containing a hiatus-filler to bridge the vowels in a standard °Łpūrṇa itihāsa$°.

My translation of this verse is tentative. Note that Łutkrānti$ (usually in similar contexts: `yogic suicide') is a Łyogāṅga$ in chapter 16. I take Łjapa$ tentatively as a stem form noun, and Łpañcavidhaḥ$ as if it read Łpañcavidhaṃ$. \BODHISBH\ 1.3.4 teaches five kinds of Łsukha$: hetusukhaṃ veditasukhaṃ duḥkhaprātipakṣikaṃ sukhaṃ veditopacchedasukham avyabādhyañ ca pañcamaṃ sukham. This would not be the first occasion in this chapter to see Buddhist categories introduced, see 11.34 above.

I think that \Ed's silent correction of °Łpradaḥ$ to °Łpradam$, making Łpāda$ d qualifying Łsādhanaṃ$ in Łpāda$ c, is reasonable, but since this form is not attasted in any of the witnesses consulted, I hesitate to follow it. Nevertheless, I understand the sentence thus: that which is normally the Łśivasaṃkalpa$ is now, in this internalised version of the forest-dweller's life, (yogic) practice that yields Łsiddhi$s. I suppose that the reference is to \VajasaneyiS\ 34.1--6, usually called ŁŚivasaṃkalpa$: yaj jāgrato dūram udaiti daivaṃ tad u suptasya tathaivaiti | dūraṃgamaṃ jyotiṣāṃ jyotir ekaṃ tan me manaḥ śivasaṃkalpam astu ||, etc. See this hymn referred to in \MANU\ 11.251 in a context of expiation: sakṛj japtvāsyavāmīyaṃ śivasaṃkalpam eva ca | apahṛtya suvarṇaṃ tu kṣaṇād bhavati nirmalaḥ ||. In Olivelle's translation: `A man who has stolen gold, on the other hand, becomes instantly stainless by reciting softly[? rather: once] the Asyavāmīya hymn and the Śivasaṃkalpa formulas.' Other texts that reference the \Sivasamkalpa\ include \NISVGUHYA\ 2.77, \AGNIP\ 259.74, and \LINPU\ 1.64.76. See more on the \Sivasamkalpa\ in RgvedaKhila and \citeyear{Sivasankalpopanisad}.
Cf. 11.23 above on giving Łabhaya$ to guests.

NOTE: In some MSS, Łpāda$ a gives a first impression of being an Łanuṣṭubh$ line with metrical problems. But, as Dominic Goodall remarked, the variants suggest that it may belong to the upcoming Śārdūlavikrīḍita verse. This is all the more so because that verse would otherwise contain only three Łpāda$s. My reconstruction of the now Łpāda$ a is still highly problematic; Łgadita$ is in stem form, and the final syllable of Łpūrvam$ scans as heavy. While these are acceptable in the language of the \VSS, some elements remain questionable, namely the first syllable of Łdharmaṃ$ as a short syllable, and the second syllable of Łavadhāritaṃ$ as long. The Łpāda$ may have gone through some heavy corruption. It is also unclear if the first half of the Łpāda$ is to be interpreted as Łvānaprastham ayaṃ$, Łvānaprastho 'yaṃ$ [Łsevet$], Łvānaprastham idaṃ$, or Łvānaprasthamayaṃ$. I translate the first of these options, taking both Łayaṃ$ and Łdharmaṃ$ as neuter nominative.
Word final syllables treated as heavy also appear in Łpāda$s bcd: °Łharaṇam$ (twice), °Łkaram$, and °Łharam$.

TEXT: susūkṣmaṃ manasā dhyātvā dṛśau pādaṃ vinikṣipet|
APP: \vb dṛśau \conj; śucau \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed\oo pādaṃ \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc; pādaṃ \msCa, pāda \msNb\Ed\oo vinikṣi° \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; ×nikṣi° \msCa, vinikṣa° \msNc
NOTE:
On meditation on the subtle one (Łsusūkṣma$), see Intro\verify.
ŁPāda$ b is suspect as it is transmitted in the MSS (in most sources: Łśucau pādaṃ vinikṣipet$: `he should place his foot in the pure'?). My conjecture (Łdṛśau$) results in something close to the early Buddhist rule given in the Pāli \Patimokkha\ on begging that says that the monk should not make eye-contact with the donor. See \Patimokkha\ Sekhiyā 7--8 and 28: okkhittacakkhu antaraghare gamissāmīti sikkhā karaṇīyā. okkhittacakkhu antaraghare nisīdissāmīti sikkhā karaṇīyā. [...] pattasaññī piṇḍapātaṃ paṭiggahessāmīti sikkhā karaṇīyā. In Bhikkhu Ñāṇatusita's translation (Patimokkha294 and 303): ` ``I shall go with the eyes cast down inside an inhabited area,'' thus the training is to be done. ``I shall sit with the eyes cast down inside an inhabited area,'' thus the training is to be done. [...] ``I shall accept alms-food paying attention to the bowl,'' thus the training is to be done.' The last of these sentences opens up another possibility for emending the text of the \VSS: Łpādaṃ$ might perhaps be considered as a corruption from Łpātraṃ$ (`on his bowl'). I am not aware of similar Dharmaśāstric teachings on avoiding eye-contact. The closest could be \BAUDHDHS\ 1.5.11 on observing silence while begging (Łvāgyatas tiṣṭhet$). Not even \MANU\ 5.50--60, a longer section on begging, prohibits eye-contact. If there are indeed no Brahmanical rules on this topic, the verse above in the \VSS\ could be another piece of evidence for Buddhist influence.
